comments.commentBody: "Henny Penny , the sky is falling". The cure is more harmful, than the disease, just like the "too big to fail bank bailout". Who benefited from the bailout? Three hundred million Americans or Warren Buffet and the Hedge Fund speculators>

Warren Buffett blasts Republicans for ‘playing Russian roulette and trying blow America’s brains out’ with debt cap defiance

Read more: http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2012649/Warren-Buffett-blasts-Re...

I don't have a new quote, but this one is worthwhile repeating, and thank you for it:

“We don’t need to tell the rest of the world that anytime people in Congress start throwing a tantrum that we’re not going to pay our bills.” — Warren E. Buffett, July 7.

What is the debt ceiling? Up until three months ago I really didn't know what it was. For about the last three months we've been taking a media driven crash course in debt ceiling 101.

Here is my take. It's a fine print type of thing written in black ink printed on page 1699 of some obscure regulatory policy. Nobody in congress really knows what it is. How do I know that? Because they don't have time to read 1699 pages of anything. Why? Because they are too busy fund raising. Or, because most members of congress can't read 1699 pages of anything thats nots non fiction.

I got news for you all. We've been an economic depressing for a couple of years now and its about to get worse.

Forget what you being told by the experts. Good ideas and cash aren't crossing paths in our streets anymore and that always leads to bad things. Trust me is not an option in fiance and politics and we are being told to trust Wall Street and Congress on a daily basis. Don't do it America, don't do it.

Here is what you should be doing. Prepare for the worse three decades of your life. Forget about job security, safe pensions, high wages, home ownership and saving for retirement until the boomers have gone to meet their maker. Each and every one of them are being orphaned by their mother land.

This entire financial crisis is not about greedy banker, brokers and politicians. Its about you and the invisible hand of the rich taking your earnings from your home, your 401K, your pensions, college fund, tax dollars, and you social security funds.

It only gets worse America, it only gets worse.

If there is no debt ceiling deal then on August 3, the interest payments get made and the rest of the Federal government gets cut approximately 40% (including the military, social security and medicare) OVERNIGHT. (If you exempt the military then the rest has to be cut more.)

Michelle Bachman refers to that hair cut as "tough love".
while all this wrangling is going on, why can't we listen to sound bites of dick cheney saying that deficits just don't matter anymore?

Disagree. Holding the debt limit is the right thing to do. Just as it would be for any individual business or individual who has "maxed out" with no sign of changing spending habits.

All the protests of financial Armageddon are a smoke screen.

Democrats are worried they won't be able to continue to "pay off" those that elected them - those on government support - entitlements and yes, government employees.

November election results show responsible Americans want fiscal sanity. Not raising the credit card limit is what tax payers (those that pay the bill) want and hopefully will get.

Republicans are doing what their constituents elected them to do.

Once we get through August 2nd without raising the limit, necessary reductions to our massive government monster will take place.

Once we cut the EPA, DOE(energy), DOE (education), Federal Reserve, NASA, DOA (agriculture), yes military too...then we move on to strike down Obamacare (ball and chain to private industry).

Less government. More capitalism.

Higher tax rates have been associated with more growth.  This is certainly part of the reason why.  The other part is that when rich people are less hungry, they gamble on junk rather than on job creating investments.  Aside from dealing with the debt crisis, the best thing that can happen for the economy is to let the Bush tax cuts expire or kill them now.

the Republicans should be happy that are not in the White House and the Americans along with them; the Trickle-down Economics does not work and in the ways the globalization and rising productivity goes there are no indications it will ever work, but the question remains is the government only reliable source of employment of the Future? Got bless America if the inept Governments should take care of the market!
Sincerely,
Joshua Konov

perhaps if david had read 'the hireless recovery' a year ago, he'd have known this already...

http://blogs.hbr.org/schrage/2010/07/hireless-recovery.html

Government Job=Private Job. Since when? That's like comparing apples to oranges. Do you really think that an economy of 1 million workers, 900,000 of which were government employees and 100,000 were private, would produce the same results of one with 900,000 private workers and 100,000 government ones? To worries about inflation we now have to add worries about conflation.

John gets very close to the real problem, and if our economists were not so blinded by Keynesian thinking, they'd "get it," too. What our government needs is a good dose of Austrian School economics. That would make them realize that the source of all busts is in the booms that preceded them. The so-called Great Depression had its roots in the roaring twenties that followed WWI. The current "greater" depression has its roots in the 40+ years since we went off the gold standard during the Vietnam War and started spending like drunken sailors. It took decades to get us into this mess, and it's gonna take decades to get us out of it.

This has to be one of the craziest posts I have ever seen. The argument seems to be that we should have increased taxes to pay for not only the workers we let go, but the additional ones we would have hired. Did the author even bother to stop and think that these government jobs add nothing to the economy and since most governments cannot operate at a deficit, required that the total amount of these payrolls would have to be taken from the productive portion of the economy.

There is no way this is a rational concept: increase employment by adding government employees because, obliviously, nothing bad could happen to the private economy.

re: "The main problem with the job market is the lack of hiring by private employers. Above all, they aren’t sure what the future will bring."

Are you falling into the Confidence Fairy thinking? Aren't they not hiring because there is no demand; that they don't like the present more than they aren't sure about the future?

The politics that gave us GW Bush now give us the Austerity Mania. No mystery there: the same folks who fell for GW and his policies are still around. But GW was proven wrong, and bad for the USA, and so too will Austerianism. First, though, it will be put into practice.

The failures of GW-ism took the USA down a notch in world history. Prepare to be taken down another notch, Americans.

FDR got nowhere with the depression for 6 years.  In 1938 he lost the Congress to conservatives, and from that point on the New Deal experimentation was over.  Then WWII came along, and FDR had to change his attitude toward the the business community -- instead of scapegoating them as he had been doing he had to partner with them for the war effort. He stripped away regulations, made a deal with unions to prevent strikes, and guaranteed many companies a profit for filling war materials orders.  From then on the economy went up like a skyrocket.

It seems to me that Republicans are reacting within a very narrow viewpoint. Money supply theory has proven its ineptness. Obama stimulus #1 spent too much money papering local and state governments and not enough in infrastructure. If money supply and Reaganomics (low tax and less regulation) worked, where are the jobs? I support another stimulus on infrastructure projects. If Republicans had allowed it originally, those projects would have been ready now, a few years later, but Republicans could not wait. I see horrible short term thinking on the part of the Republicans.

First, we need to think about globalization and its cost and benefits to our society. Labor costs in other countries could be 20 times cheaper than the US. How do we reconcile this fact? How can we save good jobs here in the US and still be competitive? Republicans want to derail unions, but unions allowed the high school graduate to support his/her family, send his children to college, own homes and pursue happiness. Minimum wage jobs do not support families. We are busy lowering our standard of living for the middle class while the rich are getting far richer. Does this approach work for a society?

This seems clear to me: if people do not have jobs, they do not spend. If people do not spend, businesses do not make products. Or, businesses find ways of cost cutting, then let more people go. Repubicans encourage this type of business climate. They say that businesses do not grow with too much uncertainty and regulation. No such thing, businesses grow when they have consumers buying their products and they expect profit. Cutting government just cuts more jobs and we go into a downhill spiral.

My concern: Republicans win the presidency. Jobs continue to slide and then Republicans see the light and stimulate the economy! Liberals, please wake up. Republicans won thge legislature and the governor of Indiana. They have gone crazy with abortion, gun laws ..not good

I am no Keynsian, but the Democrats blew it with a miseable stimulus package that did nothing to actually build serious infrastructure or invest in R&D grants/loans for the private sector. Instead they spent billions on propping up bloated state governments that did not cut back when the private sector did and have too many unproductive employees. They spent the money there because that's where the votes are...and now as the Reverend Wright would say, "The Chickens Have Come Home to Roost".because the stimulus cost roughly $240,000 on average to create what have become part-time jobs. We have president who chuckles at the topic of "Shovel Ready Jobs" which never existed. He blew a trillion dollars and is detached from millions of Americans who have and will be losing their homes. So much for the "smartest man in the room"..now there can be no Stimulus 2 because no one trusts him and the democrats to spend it wisely.The stimulus temporarily propped up up of these government jobs...and now things are truly coming home to roost as revenue in the private sector is down. State and municipal workers don't add to true economic productivity, it takes roughly almost 4 private sector folks to support the benefits and saleary of a public sector worker. If we don't cut superfluous government spending, we will go the way of Greece. Uncertainty? Darn right, why expand a business above 50 employees when you afraid of getting Obama Care?

Yes, businesses are sitting there with cash, they don't like what they see and Obama doesn't get it when he bashes the private sector in his regular efforts to create class warfare. I don't really don't blame him, he has never run a business...he doesn't get it and doesn't care, he is an idealogue. It's all Greek to him.

It is not just the loss of jobs, the people laid off were providing services. The actual value of laying people off is the savings, minus the value they provided. Since we have to pay them unemployment benefits, the actual cost is almost surely greater.  The only reason we do this at all is that the very rich figure they don't need to use public services, they can afford to send their kids to private schools, etc. For most people it is like saving money by canceling the insurance on your home; there may be an added cost. If you need an emergency room or fire truck, that cost may be obvious to you.

Government "crowding out" private investment?   Government needs to step up, much more strongly, while the private sector sits on $1.7 trillion, rakes in profits, gives double-digit raises to its CEOs, and laughs at the rest of us struggling to keep our heads above water.

I understand that 'value to society' is an economists' measure, but find it a poor term when speaking of Ms. Palin vs a doctor. Celebrities (actors, sports figures, pols etc) always earn an out-sized income. The doc, whom we call at 3AM, into whose hands we place our lives or well-being, certainly contribute more in real terms to society than the daughter of a former vp candidate, former (part-term) governor, who happens to have gotten pregnant as a teen... yet, we Americans tend to resent what we pay to ("rich") doctors, but simply be fascinated by (jealous of?) the bazillions celebs make.

The market for the services of pediatricians is hardly free. If the younger Palin had access to the services of an experienced nurse, without having to pay extra for presumptive doctor-supervision, the cost might even be lower. So the pediatrician is making extra profit, due to restriction of supply. Of course a freer market probably would not appeal to Palin, but it could benefit many others.

The chart in this post shows a subset of the data presented in the other O.E.C.D. graphic you linked to. The chart in this post presents data on "administrative burdens on start-ups,” which is one of the three components of the O.E.C.D. indicator “barriers to entrepreneurship” shown in the chart you found. (The other two components are “regulatory and administrative opacity” and “Barriers to competition.")
Well what they do is the same as always- Jack S. Hitte.
Great Depression. Anything that can be outsourced overseas will be.
